anns.prefix: Here, we identified two secreted substrates of the
anns.postfix: T6SS from the opportunistic human pathogen, Serratia marcescens.

anns.prefix: Ssp1 and Ssp2, both encoded within the T6SS gene cluster, were confirmed as
anns.postfix: delivered by the T6SS.

anns.prefix: Four related proteins encoded around the Ssp proteins (‘Rap’ proteins) included two specifically conferring
anns.postfix: (‘immunity’) against T6SS-dependent Ssp1 or Ssp2 toxicity.

anns.prefix: Four related proteins encoded around the Ssp proteins (‘Rap’ proteins) included two specifically conferring self-resistance (‘
anns.postfix: ’) against T6SS-dependent Ssp1 or Ssp2 toxicity.

anns.prefix: Homologues of the Serratia Ssp and Rap proteins are found encoded together within other T6SS gene clusters, thus they represent founder members of new families of T6SS-secreted and cognate
anns.postfix: proteins.

Molecular insight has been provided into how pathogens utilize

anns.prefix: T6SSs occur in many pathogenic bacteria and are implicated in
anns.postfix: in important pathogens, including Burkholderia mallei, Burkholderia pseudomallei, Burkholderia cenocepacia, Vibrio cholerae, Aeromonas hydrophila, Edwardsiella tarda and Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Zheng and Leung, 2007; Cascales, 2008; Jani and Cotter, 2010; de Pace et al., 2010; Burtnick et al., 2011; Rosales-Reyes et al., 2012).

anns.prefix: In several cases, the action of such ‘
anns.postfix: appears to result in disruption of the actin cytoskeleton (Pukatzki et al., 2007; Aubert et al., 2008; Suarez et al., 2010).

anns.postfix: competitors.

anns.prefix: Results Results The T6SS gene cluster harbours
anns.postfix: determinants and candidate secreted effectors The T6SS gene cluster harbours self-resistance determinants and candidate secreted effectors The T6SS gene cluster harbours self-resistance determinants and candidate secreted effectors The T6SS gene cluster of S. marcescens Db10, SMA2244–2281, contains 38 genes, including many with no known function (Murdoch et al., 2011).

anns.prefix: We speculated that encoded within this cluster might be T6-secreted effectors and/or
anns.postfix: determinants, the latter preventing the T6SS-expressing cell from harming itself or being harmed by its isogenic (sibling) neighbours.

anns.prefix: In order to determine whether the cluster did indeed contain
anns.postfix: determinants (such as specific immunity proteins analogous to the Tsi proteins), we generated a mutant lacking the entire T6SS gene cluster (ΔT6SS) and examined whether it was fully resistant to the T6SS of the wild type strain.

anns.prefix: In order to determine whether the cluster did indeed contain self-resistance determinants (such as specific
anns.postfix: proteins analogous to the Tsi proteins), we generated a mutant lacking the entire T6SS gene cluster (ΔT6SS) and examined whether it was fully resistant to the T6SS of the wild type strain.

anns.prefix: The secreted small proteins, Ssp1 and Ssp2, exert distinct harmful effects when targeted to the periplasm in Escherichia coli and are neutralized by coexpression of the cognate
anns.postfix: protein The secreted small proteins, Ssp1 and Ssp2, exert distinct harmful effects when targeted to the periplasm in Escherichia coli and are neutralized by coexpression of the cognate immunity protein The secreted small proteins, Ssp1 and Ssp2, exert distinct harmful effects when targeted to the periplasm in Escherichia coli and are neutralized by coexpression of the cognate immunity protein In order to confirm the antibacterial toxin function of Ssp1 and Ssp2 and establish in which cellular compartment they exerted their effect, each protein was produced in E. coli, either in the cytoplasm or artificially targeted to the periplasm (by the N-terminal fusion of the Sec-dependent OmpA signal peptide: sp-Ssp2 or sp-Ssp1).

anns.prefix: The presence of Ssp2 in the periplasm, but not the cytoplasm, prevented growth of E. coli on LB and minimal media; this
anns.postfix: was alleviated by the co-production of Rap2ab (Fig. 5A).

anns.prefix: Periplasmic Ssp1 was also
anns.postfix: and its effect alleviated by co-production of Rap1ab (Fig. 5A).

anns.prefix: However Ssp1
anns.postfix: was only observed at higher expression levels and on minimal media.

anns.prefix: Discussion Discussion In this study we have identified two proteins, Ssp1 and Ssp2, as true (non-structural) secreted substrates of the
anns.postfix: T6SS and confirmed them as new T6SS-dependent antibacterial toxins.

anns.prefix: In this study we have identified two proteins, Ssp1 and Ssp2, as true (non-structural) secreted substrates of the
anns.postfix: T6SS and confirmed them as new T6SS-dependent antibacterial toxins.

anns.prefix: It seems clear that Ssp1 and Ssp2 are not the only effector proteins secreted by the
anns.postfix: T6SS.

anns.prefix: First, Ssp mutants are still able to kill
anns.postfix: as effectively as wild type Db10 (Fig. S4), implying that other toxins secreted in their absence are sufficient to maintain efficient antibacterial killing.

anns.prefix: Indeed, our unpublished work has identified four other, unrelated, candidate substrates of the
anns.postfix: T6SS.

anns.prefix: Hence, we believe that
anns.postfix: uses a species-specific arsenal of secreted toxins to produce the potent and efficient targeting of a variety of competitor bacteria observed (Murdoch et al., 2011).

anns.prefix: Ssp- and Rap-like proteins are found associated with a subset of T6SSs (some, but not all, closely related to the
anns.postfix: T6SS), but whether these T6SSs all exhibit antibacterial activity remains to be determined.

anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: Rap proteins represent founder members of a new bacterial protein family, members of which represent immunity proteins for T6-secreted toxins, as exemplified by Rap1a and Rap2a.

anns.prefix: In summary, our data support a model (Fig. 8) whereby Ssp1 and Ssp2 are toxins secreted by the
anns.postfix: T6SS into the periplasm of a neighbouring cell.

anns.prefix: We believe that other effectors most likely act on different cellular targets, analogous to the
anns.postfix: , cytoplasmic-acting toxin, Tse2 (Li et al., 2012).

anns.prefix: Finally, we speculate that as the Ssp and Rap proteins are encoded within the T6SS gene cluster, and related genes are found associated with other T6SSs, particularly closely related ones, they may represent the ancestral substrates of the
anns.postfix: T6SS.
